hobby.message: Any new mods on your FPV quad?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Feels colder, yeah. City's always shifting lately.
I do analog photography. Mostly street scenes, not much else.
Last week, lot of people on edge. Makes getting shots harder.
You notice the tension everywhere.
Colder? Maybe everyone's just watching each other closer now.
I shoot film. Old-school 35mm—keeps me focused, you know?
Since the leaks, everyone's jumpy. Caught someone blocking their face yesterday.
I keep my camera hidden. Not worth trouble if security's out.
You can't capture what's not there anymore.
Yeah, it's colder—like the walls have ears, even in here.
I spend my free hours shooting street photos on real film.
Last weekend near Unity Square, everyone wanted to fade into the background.
The protest crowds are restless, but those moments are honest.
Film's precious now, especially since the leaks exposed so much.
I keep shooting. It's the only truth I trust.
Feels colder, sure. Not just the weather—it's how people move now.
I sneak around with my 35mm all the time. Analog street shots, real moments.
The night after the vote, people asked for photos. Wanted 'evidence' of being there.
Once the leaks dropped, the mood snapped. Got yelled at for just raising my camera.
Film's hard to get, riskier to develop. Worth it, though.
There are faces in those frames—defiance, hope, pure fear.
Half my rolls are still undeveloped, just waiting for the right time.
Definitely colder. Not just outside—it's in how folks look through you now.
I run old analog film. 35mm, smuggled from the east, shot in alleys and protests.
Started out just wanting to document the city I knew. Now it's documenting a cover-up.
Vote night, strangers lined up for portraits—like it might matter to someone, someday.
When the leaks hit, I dodged two checkpoints just to save a half-finished roll.
I keep undeveloped film hidden at home. Can't risk bringing it to the state lab.
Used to be a hobby. Now it feels like an act of resistance.
The lens shows fear, sure. But it also shows who's still refusing to disappear.
hobby_answer: Yeah, it survived. Barely.
Film’s hard to get. Developing is trickier now, with checkpoints.
Mostly shoot empty streets these days. Safer not to have people in frame.
Since the leak, carrying a camera attracts all the wrong attention.
Keeping my rolls hidden is half the hobby now.
Survived, for now. Not easy though.
Film costs triple since last week’s chaos.
People flinch at the sight of a lens now.
After the voting scandal broke, security’s everywhere.
Even getting prints made feels like a risk lately.
Some nights, I just shoot walls and shadows.
Still going. Analog never dies that easily.
Had my camera at the protests after the vote.
Captured some honest faces, fear and hope mixed up.
That leak changed everything—people want a photo to prove they existed.
Now, I stash my rolls deep. Haven’t seen a proper lab open in days.
Most of the old photo spots are ghosted since they cracked down.
Strangest part? The photos feel heavier now. Like evidence.
Hanging on. Analog’s stubborn, just like me.
Shot the crowds outside the broadcast, felt electric.
Post-vote, people begged for portraits—maybe their only record if things turn worse.
Once the leak hit, checkpoints went up. Had to hide my camera under my jacket.
Got chased off when security scanned for 'unregistered devices.'
Spent hours waiting out curfew in a stairwell, film sweating in my pocket.
Printed a few shots in my bathroom sink.
Feels like these frames might matter to someone, someday.
Yep, analog survived. Feels like a secret rebellion now.
Been shooting street scenes since my dad ran BCI drills downtown.
Old Minolta’s witnessed more truth than any Council feed ever will.
After that rigged vote leak, everyone looked at cameras differently—desperate, or suspicious.
Crowds actually invited me to take their picture. Proof of being there, they said.
Spent half the night dodging random device scans. Had to ditch a lens behind a dumpster.
Two rolls almost ruined from sweat—my bathroom’s become my darkroom sanctuary.
Used to think I was documenting boredom. Now every frame feels historic.
Somewhere in this city’s shadow, real life’s still bleeding onto film.
